name: HD 160691
scenarioDescription:
The HD 160691 Exoplanetary System

HD 160691 is a star with 1.08 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.0859999999999999 times its radius. It is located 50.91 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 160691 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 160691 b

HD 160691 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2001-07. Its semi-major axis is 1.50 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 643.25 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 160691.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.128, which means that when HD 160691 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 1.31 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 1.69. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 160691 b is 532.65 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

HD 160691 c

HD 160691 c was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2004-12. Its semi-major axis is 5.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4205.80 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 160691.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.0985, which means that when HD 160691 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 4.72 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 5.75. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 160691 c is 576.51 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

HD 160691 d

HD 160691 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2004-10. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.64 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 160691.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.172, which means that when HD 160691 d is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.08 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.11. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 160691 d is 10.55 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 160691 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

HD 160691 e

HD 160691 e was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2007-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.92 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 310.55 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 160691.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.0666, which means that when HD 160691 e is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.86 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.98. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 160691 e is 165.87 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 e is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 160691, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Anglo-Australian Telescope.
